Dialogue.Line: House guests leaving the conservatory, entering the library.

House guests leaving the nursery. Wait! Something's wrong. One of them's a girl.

Dialogue.Line: Behold, the end of the war.
So, this is what brought you here. A natural source of lethal poisons.
The Curse of Fenric.
Once the Nazis see what our planes are dropping on their cities
But you can't!
It'll mean the end of the war. Save hundreds of thousands of lives.
More horrible than the Well of Hvergelmir.
What did you say?
The Well of Hvergelmir, deep beneath the ground where broods of serpents spew their venom over the roots of the Great Ash Tree.
The Great Ash Tree. The soul of all the Earth.
Professor?
Shush.
We have seen it, Doctor. You and I. We have seen hell. Come, I'll show you it all.
What's he on about?
Norse mythology. It seems that I've persuaded him that I'm on his side.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes a long look at the green death dripping into the tank before following Millington and the Doctor back through the underground rooms.
The Russians are very happy with their glorious victory.

Dialogue.Line: You should have seen him. With his bare hands. When it comes to killing, the sarge is an expert.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov is the only one not laughing.

Dialogue.Line: Prozorov. These things have to be done.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reverend Wainwright is sitting in a pew when Millington, the Doctor and Ace come out of the vestry.

Dialogue.Line: Professor.
Hmm?
What's wrong with the vicar?
No girls. Leave her here.
What? You're beginning to aggravate me.
Don't antagonise him, Ace. You'd better stay here.
Professor.
Only for a short time. I've got to find out what is going on, and you can find out what's wrong with Mister Wainwright.
All right.
Coming, Commander. (to Ace) Give me an hour.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Millington leave. Ace sits with Wainwright.

Dialogue.Line: Funny church, this, isn't it?
I was just remembering when I was a child. My father was the vicar here then. It seemed such a warm, friendly place in those days.
Things always look different when you're a child.
Now I stand in the church every Sunday, I see all the faces looking up at me, waiting for me to give them something to believe in.
Don't you believe in anything?
I used to believe there was good in the world, hope for the future.
The future's not so bad. Have faith in me.
Ah, Millington. I need the central rotor unit unlocking.
The Ultima machine.
Of course, you haven't seen it, have you? A completely automatic computing machine, the most advanced in the world.
Remarkable for the nineteen forties.
This is just the bait.
For the Germans?
Russians.
But they're your allies.
After the war, when they're no longer allies. This is what the Russians want. The mind of the Ultima machine.
More than a thousand combinations an hour, with automatic negative checking.
And we are going to let the Russians steal it. Orders from Whitehall. Look inside, Doctor. Look deep inside.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the heart of the computer is a flask of green poison.
Miss Hardaker has found the damp swimming costumes, and is berating her lodgers.

Dialogue.Line: You will burn in the everlasting fires of hell! You wicked, evil girls!
Just because you've never been swimming.
You have black hearts! There's no love in heaven or earth for you. Nothing for you but pitiless damnation for the rest of your lives! Think on it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phyllis and Jean walk out.
There is a large number of bombs neatly stacked against the wall, and men in long lab coats working in the background. Millington goes to a containment chamber.

Dialogue.Line: A demonstration, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One man takes a cage of doves into the chamber while Millington uses the thick rubber gloves sealed to the front glass to pick up a vial of green liquid.

Dialogue.Line: This small capsule contains just a few drops of diluted toxin.
No, don't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Millington breaks the vial and gas begins to fill the chamber.

Dialogue.Line: Just think what a bomb full could do to a city like Dresden or Moscow.
It's inhuman.
It could mean the end of the war.
And Whitehall thinks that Moscow is careless enough to let you detonate one of those things inside the Kremlin?

Oh, that's the beauty of it, Doctor. We won't detonate it. They'll do it themselves. They'll use the machine to decrypt our ciphers, but Doctor Judson has programmed it to self-destruct when it tries to decrypt a particular word. And, once the political climate is appropriate, we will include the word in one of our ciphers.
And the word is?
What else could it be, Doctor? Love.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two marines are working underground when a humming noise pushes some bricks out of the wall.

Dialogue.Line: What was that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The missing bricks reveal a three handled flask in the cavity. The soldier takes it out.

Dialogue.Line: Is this ours?
Is it marked government property?
No.
Nothing to do with us then. Leave it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldier drops the old flask.

Dialogue.Line: Right, let's get this sealed up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov is washing his face in the water when Phyllis and Jean run into the sea, still clothed.

Dialogue.Line: I don't care if I've got nothing to wear!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He leaves without them seeing him.

Dialogue.Line: It's so warm and peaceful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A mist begins to drift across the water.

Dialogue.Line: Here, Philly. What's that?
What is it?
It's a sort of mist.
So what? Who cares? It's warm in the water.
Yeah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mist thickens and the girls disappear from sight.

Dialogue.Line: Philly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As quickly as it came, the mist disperses to reveal an empty cove.
Captain Bates enters.

Dialogue.Line: Yes?
I thought you'd like to know, sir. They've finished closing down operations over at the church.
Good. Tell me, they didn't find anything unusual, did they?
Not to my knowledge, sir.
I can't take any more risks. I want all radio transmitters and outside telephone lines disabling.
That may attract attention, sir.
Do it.
Sir!
And if there are any chess sets in the camp, I want them burnt.
Chess sets?
Burnt!
Sir!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bates leaves. Millington returns to his sketch of a bottle on War Office stationry.

Dialogue.Line: **[Bunk room] **
Sorry, girls. Commander's orders. No more chess sets.
Don't you find the Commander's orders a little peculiar sometimes, soldier?
Peculiar or not, orders is orders. Come on girls, let's have your chess set.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kathleen has her baby in her cot on the bunk.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. What are you going to do with her?
Oh, something will turn up. One of the girls has gone to ask her sister if Audrey can stay with her for a few days till I sort something out. Do you have any family yourself?
I don't know.
Oh, I'm sorry. It's the war, isn't it? It must be terrible not knowing.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Judson is writing the final set of runes on the machine when the Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: You haven't seen Ace at all? I'm getting a little worried.
Quiet! Now, let's see what lies encrypted in these carvings, hmm?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The tickertape printer rattles.

Dialogue.Line: (reads) Let the chains of Fenric shatter. Even with an alphabet more than a thousand years old, the Ultima machine can reveal it's meaning.
It can translate it, but who knows what it might mean? CRANE: But who cares?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov is on the beach, looking at Jean and Phyllis standing up to their waists in the water. Their hair is now loose, their skin deathly pale and their nails a good three inches long.

Dialogue.Line: Look.
Yes, a man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov approaches the waters edge.

Dialogue.Line: Are you looking at us?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov wades in.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, he's watching us.
He's got to come into the water with us.
Yes, you've got to come into the water.
It's warm.
Blood warm. Nobody's forcing him. Nobody ever forces you to come into the water.
But everybody wants to. Deep down, everybody wants to come into the water.
Come on. Come play with us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As he nears the girls, other creatures reach up and grab him. They drag him under, screaming.

Dialogue.Line: Oh yes, yes, I've known Millington since before my accident.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hiya.
Ah, good. Oh, I need to have a word with your two young friends.
Jean and Phyllis?
Yes.
They'll be with the old dragon.
Good. Back in a mo. I'm just going to requisition some transport.
Bags I drive!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves and Ace starts playing the logic game. The rattle annoys Judson.

Dialogue.Line: Shut up. I said, shut up!
I know what it is.
I am trying to work.
I know what the inscription means.
Yes, yes. I already know. Let the chains of Fenric shatter. I already know that.
No, no, no. It's a logic diagram.
What?
Look, this is a logic diagram for the flip-flop thingy, right?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Judson nods.

Dialogue.Line: And this is a logic diagram for something else.
But it's so complex.
That's because it's not for a small thing like this. It's for a computer.
Crane! Take me to the decrypt room!
And the half-time score, Perivale six hundred million, rest of the universe nil.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Miss Hardaker carefully lowers the stylus onto a gramophone record, and smiles at the music. Then a curtain is pulled aside from a doorway and the smile quickly vanishes. It is the evil Jean and Phyllis.

Dialogue.Line: No! No! No, I beg you! No! No! Argh!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov floats face down in the sea at Maidens Point.

Dialogue.Line: Hello? Anybody home?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The music has long since finished, and the stylus grinds round the middle of the record. The Doctor lifts it off.

Dialogue.Line: Professor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Miss Hardaker is lying back in her easy chair, eyes staring out of a white face, and with scratches on her neck.

Dialogue.Line: Looks like the one at Maidens Point. Completely drained of blood.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reverend Wainwright stands amongst the gravestones holding a Bible, while Jean and Phyllis slowly creep up behind him.

Dialogue.Line: I know who you are.
You've always known us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wainwright turns around.

Dialogue.Line: But vampires are just superstition. Why?
We have black hearts. We were lost on the day we were born.
That's not true. No one is lost.
Everyone is lost.
No further. This is holy. It will destroy you.
Objects can't harm us. It's human belief, and you stopped believing when the bombs started falling.
I'm not frightened of German bombs.
Not German bombs, British.
On German cities. British bombs killing German children.
No. No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor runs in between the girls and Wainwright.

Dialogue.Line: Stop!
What's happened to you? What are you doing?
You should have come into the water with us. Then we'd have been together.
Go! Go!
We go, but we'll return for you, Wainwright.
This is it, Judson.
A little respect for the wheelchair, please, Commander. He's an invalid.
I'm not an invalid, I'm a cripple. I'm also a genius, so shut up, the pair of you.
All that remains is the flask. The machine can unlock its secrets.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Down in the tunnel, the discarded flask glows green. Judson pushes a cylinder back into the Ultima machine.

Dialogue.Line: Now then, Millington. Let's see, shall we?
Yes, quick!
We must tell Commander Millington.

No, that's exactly what we won't do. He'll just go around shooting everything. No, as long as Doctor Judson doesn't work out what the inscription is, it'll keep them out of harms way. And he's a typical blinkered scientist.
Oh no! You should have told me.
Quick! We'd better stop them!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They run. The flask glows brighter green and drowned people rise from the sea at Maidens Point, heading for the shore. Some are still human, others are completely transformed.
Bates enters.

Dialogue.Line: Captain, no one is to touch the Ultima machine. It must complete it's task.
Sir.
Just one problem. You've weakened the bases' defences precisely so some Russians could steal it.
Captain, radio for reinforcements.
Sir, you've just ordered that all radio transmitters be disabled. I've just set Perkins onto it now.
What!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Perkins is obeying his orders with an axe when Millington enters.

Dialogue.Line: Sir. Radio transmitters disabled, as ordered, sir.
Splendid work, Perkins. Splendid work. Now put them back together again.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Ace and Reverend Wainwright leave building 49. It is raining hard, and the Doctor's umbrella gets put to conventional use.

Dialogue.Line: We haven't got much time.
But Jean and Phyllis?
Dark legends. In the story of Dracula, this is where he came ashore.
Vampires?
No, not vampires, haemovores. They are what Homo sapiens evolve into thousands of years in the future. Creatures with an insatiable hunger for blood.
I don't understand. The future? How can you know?
I've seen it. How good are your parish records?
Oh, they go back as far as the 18th century.
Good. Now for a little local history.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace hesitates.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
I was just thinking. If these vampires, I mean haemovores, if they come here. Well, Kathleen and her little baby.
Look, once upon a time you'd have dropped everything just for a little bit of excitement.
Yeah, but I just want to make sure they're all right.
Catch us up.
Thanks.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor.
Hmm?
Those two girls. They said they'd come back for me. DOCTOR: Do you want to stay here?
No. No, no I can't. Come, Doctor, the parish records.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Prozorov is lying on the beach, dead. Sorin closes his eyes and takes the identification papers from the man's tunic.

Dialogue.Line: I'm sorry, Kapitan. I know you and the sergeant had been friends a long time. Kapitan. Kapitan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Haemovores are coming along the beach towards them.

Dialogue.Line: On your command.
Save your bullets. Everyone pulls back, and don't turn away from them or you're dead. Take him. Come on! Move, move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Russians carry Prozorov away.
Kathleen is packing her suitcase when Ace enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hiya. How's the little horror?
(sotto) Well, I've just fed her and put her down.
Oh, I'm sorry. You should have told me. (The baby wakes.) Where will you go?
Oh, I'll manage. Frank's got shore leave in a few weeks.
Who's Frank? Your boyfriend?
No, my husband.
Oh, I didn't know you were married.
I've got a baby.
Yeah, I just thought that
Well, you can stop thinking it, all right?
Oh, I, I didn't know.
It's okay. It's okay.
Where is he?
He's in the Merchant Navy, Atlantic convoys.
I used to think I'll never get married, but now I'm not so sure. There's a lot of things I'm not sure about now.
It's the war, Ace.
Yeah. Look, take care, won't you?
Thanks, you too.
No, I mean really take care.
We're wasting our time on some superstition.
The Viking legends will come true. The treasure will be brought to us, and with it all the dark powers of Fenric shall be ours.
Oh yes, I know. Let the chains of Fenric shatter. Well, what about my chains?
That was over twenty years ago. Why must you remind me? I offer you everything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Russians watch from the top of the cliff as Jean and Phyllis lead the haemovores along the beach.

Dialogue.Line: Kapitan, what are they?

Six months ago, a small sabotage team was sent into German occupied Romania. Only one survived. He talked about dead men coming out of a black fog. The official report said he'd been listening to too much local gossip about vampires.
But vampires don't exist.
Of course not.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin starts sharpening a wooden stake.
The Doctor and Reverend Wainwright are looking through a pre-1837 Church Register when Ace enters.

Dialogue.Line: Why does your bell tower look like a fortress? Like the people who built it were expecting trouble.
I don't think there's a record of any battles taking place here.
Today's events haven't been written down yet. Now, you're looking for the descendants of the early Viking settlers about two hundred years ago. Ace, you help me.
So what exactly are we looking for?
The Viking inscriptions said they were carrying treasures from the Orient.
You might give me something to go on. I mean, a few hints might be useful.
Well, just look for something evil.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tips up a box then drops it on his foot. Ace finds the flask next door.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor! Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace puts the flask in her rucksack then follows the Doctor to find out what Wainwright wants.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, I've found it. Exactly as you said.
What you got, vicar?
There's your Vikings, or descendants of them at any rate. (reads) Joseph Sundvik, Florence Sundvik, wife. Daughters Sarah, Martha, Jane, Clara, Annie.
The curse of Fenric, passed down through the generations.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The mist swirls around the Sundvik family tombstone, and the transformed Joseph and Florence rise up from their grave.

Dialogue.Line: Find out which daughters married, and what their new surnames are.
Professor, what's this water doing here?
Oh, it's the roof. It leaks. It always seeps in like that when it's raining and there's an east wind.
The problem is, it's not raining. There's a west wind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Clawed hands reach around the wooden door. The Doctor and Ace push it shut but more try to come in from the outside door. Wainwright tries to keep them out, then a haemovore smashes the small window that looks into the church and grabs Ace. The Doctor pulls her free as the creatures start to smash down the door and grab her again. She gets free and grabs a pair candlesticks.

Dialogue.Line: Vicar!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace hands one to Wainwright, who uses it to hit the grasping hands, and uses the second on some haemovores before she loses it and runs up the steps to the bell tower.

More haemovores are clawing at the main church door, and still more coming along the church path. Ace gets her metal ladder out of her rucksack and rolls it out over the side of the tower then climbs down only to fall into the clutches of more haemovores on the roof of the vestry. Sorin and his two troops arrive and see her fighting.

Dialogue.Line: Follow me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One haemovore pins Ace's arms while the second prepares to slash her. Sorin climbs up and over the battlement.

Dialogue.Line: Takes two against one, does it? How about a little Cossack blood, eh?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovores push Ace behind them and face the fresh meat.

Dialogue.Line: Fire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Several bullets finally knock the haemovores down.

Dialogue.Line: Up the ladder, quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovores get up, and the impact of more bullets knocks them down again. Ace climbs the ladder.

Dialogue.Line: Go, quick!
Hold them! Hold them!
I don't know that I can!
You've got to have faith! Have faith. Faith. Faith.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor steps back into the middle of the room and concentrates. The haemovores enter from the church, then clutch their heads and scream. They all leave. Ace comes back down the bell tower steps. There is the sound of gunshots and then thuds on the roof.
Sorin and his men have stuck wooden stakes through the hearts of their attackers, who have promptly melted like good little vampires.

Dialogue.Line: We won't have any more trouble from those two. Quick, up the ladder.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin and his men make their way between the bells with Ace's rucksack, and join them. The Doctor finally relaxes.

Dialogue.Line: Ah. Any more up there?
Only those creatures.
Quick, you and your men, down to the crypt.
Down.
Get the record books.
Right.
Hurry up!
Yes!
Jam the door.
Professor, that noise you were making. Like singing, only it wasn't.
Ah, just a little something to frighten off haemovores.
I thought vampires were scared of crucifixes.
No, no, it's not the crucifix that frightens them, it's the faith of the person carrying it. It creates a psychic barrier, just like I did.
Door's secure.
We're trapped.
Ace?
The mine shaft.
Correct. (The Doctor opens the secret doorway.)
Listen, I must go back to my men.
You can't go back that way. Those creatures, they're, they're inhuman.
I must try. If I fail, I fail. These two will stay with you.
Professor, show him how to make the singing.
I can't. Either he believes absolutely, or he doesn't.
I believe in the Revolution.
Complete faith? No doubts?
Go. If we meet again, you will have your answer. Go.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Wainwright and the soldiers leave. Ace touches Sorin's arm. He takes off his white silk scarf and ties it loosely around her neck.

Dialogue.Line: Be careful.
I hope we're not too late.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor discovers the two soldier's handiwork.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no!
What's happened?
You two, break that wall down. Quick, quick!
If you want a job doing properly, get a girl to do it. Out of the way, boys.
Ace! Oh, don't antagonise her. It'll only make things worse.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes two cans of Nitro Nine and primes them.

Dialogue.Line: Five seconds and you're yesterday's breakfast, sunbeam.
Take cover!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all hide behind the wall in the next room. Boom!

Dialogue.Line: Wicked.
Quick, get in the tunnel! (to Ace) I'll talk to you later.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Upstairs in the vestry, Sorin is confronted by Jean and Phyllis. He removes his red star and holds it. The girls and the other haemovores clutch at their heads and scream. He walks through them unharmed.

Dialogue.Line: How much further?
Three or four hundred metres.
Oh, we'll never make it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes the flask from her rucksack, but the Doctor doesn't look at it.

Dialogue.Line: What's the matter?
Well, if I get the top off this, then I can make up some more nitro.
Another explosion might bring the roof down on top of our heads.
Oh, just a small one?
No!
If only we could slow them down for a few moments.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldiers cock their rifles.

Dialogue.Line: Two minutes, then follow us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The soldiers go back up the tunnel. The Doctor finally notices the flask.

Dialogue.Line: Where did you find that?
It was just lying around.
That's the Oriental treasure we've been looking for.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Now safely outside the church, Sorin breathes again when the haemovores walk away from him. Jean and Phyllis lead their group into the tunnel.
Sorin joins Vershinin and the rest of his men overlooking the cove.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening? The air, it's so still and so warm.
There is a storm coming on.
Come on! You're almost here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace takes back the flask. Behind them comes the sound of rapid gunfire.
Ace, the Doctor and Wainwright run out of a pair of metal doors.

Dialogue.Line: Right, seal it.
But there are two people following us.
You're here, that's all I'm interested in. And I'll have those.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Millington takes the church registers while the Doctor tussles with the marines and the Russians hammer on the closed doors.

Dialogue.Line: Open those doors!
Many years ago, when I was Chief Petty Officer on board ship, we had an explosion in an engine room.
But the Russians are our friends, our allies!
I had to seal it off to save the ship, keep the flames restricted to one section.
Please, Commander. Those two men won't stand a chance against those creatures. They're inhuman!
So's he.
We could hear men screaming behind the bulkheads for nearly an hour, and then the screaming stopped.
But, but

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Russians cut the barbed wire. Sorin swaps his tin lid for his uniform cap.

Dialogue.Line: Okay. You stay here. If I'm not back in ten minutes, abort the mission. Take this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin hands Vershinin a backpack.

Dialogue.Line: Take cover.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vershinin and the soldiers don't quite hide behind a small tree as Sorin goes through the gap in the fence.

Dialogue.Line: Commander Millington! Commander Millington, I want to talk with you, officer to officer!
Here we are, Judson. I said it would be brought to us. Release the power.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Judson takes the flask.

Dialogue.Line: Sir, the house guests have arrived.
What?
The house guests. There's one outside. He wants to talk to you.
Talk?
We must talk, Commander Millington.
I'm afraid you have me at a disadvantage. You seem to know my name, but I don't know yours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A lot of weapons are aimed at Sorin from a distance.

Dialogue.Line: However, that hardly seems to matter at the moment. You will tell your men to put down their weapons and surrender.
I come alone. Very well. (shouts) Lay down your weapons and come in peacefully, like the wolves of winter.
Move! Move back! Move it! Let's get out of here!
Lock him up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin is taken away. The Doctor arrives.

Dialogue.Line: You'll be pleased to know, Doctor, everything is under control.
The Russians aren't your problem, those creatures are. They devour humans the way you eat fruit.
I doubt if any creatures can walk through iron shutters.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up the piece of metal from Maidens Point.

Dialogue.Line: They can weld metal beneath the sea with their bare hands.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The metal doors to the tunnel are starting to melt.
Kathleen is sitting silently on a bed, holding a letter.

Dialogue.Line: You all right? What is it? What's wrong? Tell me. What's the matter? I'll do anything.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kathleen gives the letter to Ace.

Dialogue.Line: What's this? (reads) It is with deepest sorrow that I write to inform you that the ship on which your husband, Frank William Dudman, was serving, was struck by enemy torpedoes. Your husband was trapped in the fire and has been listed as missing, presumed dead. Please accept our sincere condolences. I'm sorry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two women weep in each others arms as the Ultima machine prints out more names. Estrid, Sigvald, Hakon, Fridrek, Wulfstan.
Ace confronts the Doctor in the open.

Dialogue.Line: You know what's going on, don't you?
Yes.

You always know. You just can't be bothered to tell anyone. It's like it's some kind of game, and only you know the rules. You knew all about that inscription being a computer programme, but you didn't tell me. You know all about that old bottle, and you're not telling me. Am I so stupid?
No, that's not it.
Why then? I want to know.
Evil. Evil since the dawn of time.
What do you mean?
Will you stop asking me these questions?
Tell me!

The dawn of time. The beginning of all beginnings. Two forces only, good and evil. Then chaos. Time is born, matter, space. The universe cries out like a newborn. The forces shatter as the universe explodes outwards. Only echoes remain, and yet somehow, somehow the evil force survives. An intelligence. Pure evil!
That's Fenric?
No, that's just Millington's name for it. Evil has no name. Trapped inside a flask like a genie in a bottle.
Can we stop it?
We need to get that flask.
We can release Captain Sorin to help us. I can distract the guard.
How?
Professor, I'm not a little girl.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Reverend Wainwright watches the metal doors to the tunnel melting.

Dialogue.Line: Are you looking for someone?
No. You.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace walks away and Sergeant Leigh follows her.

Dialogue.Line: There's a wind whipping up. I can feel it through my clothes. Is there a storm coming?
I wasn't expecting one.
The question is, is he making all the right moves or only going through the motions?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace leads Leigh away around the corner, and the Doctor runs across the open space unseen into the guard room. The keys to the cell are in a desk drawer. The Doctor frees Sorin and they leave.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing here?
You have to move faster than that if you want to keep up with me. Faster than light.
Faster than the second hand on a watch?
Much faster. We're not even moving yet. Hardly cruising speed. Sometimes I move so fast, I don't exist any more.
What can you see?
Undercurrents, bringing things to the surface.
I can't stay.
You promised.
I can't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean, Phyllis and the haemovores break out of the tunnel.

Dialogue.Line: I'm here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He holds out his Bible.

Dialogue.Line: The book won't do you any good. You don't believe.
We'll see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They take a step back and scream as Wainwright looks heavenwards and prays.
Ace joins the Doctor and Sorin.

Dialogue.Line: You all right?
Yeah, nothing out of my depth.
Come on.
How are we going to stop Fenric?
Evil needs a body. It hasn't found one yet.
Thank you.
It's not true. You don't believe it.
Look at us. There's no good in us.
No! I believe in good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But the seed of doubt has been sown.

Dialogue.Line: Look in yourself. There's no good in you.
No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovores stop screaming and move forward.

Dialogue.Line: No! No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He disappears beneath their claws.
A frightened Kathleen is singing to her baby in the noisy storm.

Dialogue.Line: When the bough breaks, the cradle will fall. Down will come baby, cradle and all.
You left me in the shadow dimensions, trapped for seventeen centuries. But now I've found a body again, and the preparations are complete.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Judson raises his arms. A window blows in and he vanishes. Bates and a marine enter.

Dialogue.Line: Shoot them!
What for?
Because I order you to. For treason.
Sir.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Captain Bates takes the Doctor's weapon, that is, his umbrella, from him.
Judson materialises underground in front of someone.

Dialogue.Line: I was only expecting one.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A firing squad forms up in the pouring rain in front of a wall. Sorin stands with the Doctor and Ace awaiting his fate.

Dialogue.Line: You don't have to kill her.
Let's just get this over with. Ready!
She's only a child!
Aim!
Killing us doesn't make any difference.
Mum, I'm sorry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vershinin throws a grenade, and the marines scatter.

Dialogue.Line: Take cover!
Hurry! Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Under cover of more grenades and gunfire, the Doctor, Ace and Sorin make it to the Russian lines.
Judson has appeared in front of Jean and Phyllis.

Dialogue.Line: I was hoping for something a little more, well, Aryan. However, let the Ancient One approach. Where is the Ancient One?
He waits.
He waits? He waits? What for? Has he no sense of occasion? I want him here, now.
As you command.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two marines start shooting. The haemovores deal with them.
The Doctor and Ace are hiding from the rain and the bullets.

Dialogue.Line: What did you say over there?
What?
Over there. You said something.
Oh, nothing. Just, just something.
You mentioned your mum.
Don't play games with me, Doctor.
We're all playing games. Fenric's games. We're playing his games and falling into his traps.
And the battlefield shall stretch a hundred leagues, and at the end of the day not one living thing shall be left alive. The ancient enemies shall seek each other out, and all shall die!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Millington drips rain water onto his chess set.
Jean and Phyllis stand over the freshly drained Marines.

Dialogue.Line: How English. Everything stops for tea. Fetch me the ancient one. There is much to do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean and Phyllis bow, and turn.

Dialogue.Line: I must play the game to the end this time.
What game?
A very simple game. A game of chess.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The marines have settled in behind some sandbags.

Dialogue.Line: Move it, move it.!
I need a chess set to play the game. I need pieces.
If we can get into Commander Millington's office, we could nick his chess set.
Hey, we came here to steal Ultima machine. Chess set? No problem. Follow.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Ace follow Sorin to the corner of the nearest building.

Dialogue.Line: We've got a clear path to the British positions. Go. (Meanwhile, on the other side of the fight.)
Establish new positions. Secure the laboratory.
Follow me!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jean and Phyllis look out to sea and raise their arms.

Dialogue.Line: You are summoned. JEAN + PHYLLIS: You must obey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Lightning strikes the water, and a fully mutated haemovore rises and walks to shore.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, the sound of dying. When it comes to death, quantity is so much more satisfying than quality.
The final
Don't interrupt me when I'm eulogising. Where is the Time Lord?
Time Lord?
The one you call Doctor.
I had him shot.

I can see you've never been handicapped by great intelligence. For seventeen centuries I was trapped in the shadow dimensions because of him. He pulled bones from the desert sands and carved them into chess pieces. He challenged me to solve his puzzle. I failed. Now I shall see him kneel before me before I let him die.
Here's the chess set.
No, no! Don't touch!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Too late. A wire has been pulled, and gas begins to pour from a hole hidden below the pile of Church records. The Doctor puts a waste paper basket over the hole to contain it.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, thanks. I don't know why he used a chemical grenade. If I was him, I've have stuck a few sticks of explosives under the table.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They look under the table and sure enough - there are the sticks of dynamite and a dangling detonator pin. The Doctor grabs Ace's arm and they run out of building 48, throwing themselves over some sandbags just as the whole building goes KaBOOM!
The ancient one has obeyed the summons.

Dialogue.Line: At last, another of the Wolves of Fenric decides to show up and play his role.
My world is dead.
Hardly a great loss, if you're the best evolution could manage. This is the 20th century. It doesn't become your world for a long time yet. First, you must kill all humans.
Another of Fenric's traps.
Well, at least I managed to grab the consolation prize.
Ha, ha, well done. The parish records. Great.
What I can't understand is what's so special about them.
Names.
Whose names?
Names of ancient families. Judson, Millington, Wainwright, Dudman.
Dudman! Kathleen Dudman, she's got a chess set.
No, no, no. Millington destroyed them all.
No, no. I saw it in her suitcase.
Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Wrens are hiding in the typing pool when the door opens. They scream.
Captain Bates puts a vial of green poison gas into a grenade.

Dialogue.Line: Ready? Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He pulls the pin, goes to the corner of the building and throws it. The marines start up covering fire. The grenades land in the sandbagged area where two Russians are. They die quickly but noisily. A little later, the fighting has finished. Millington and Bates survey the dead.

Dialogue.Line: Are they Russians?
Russians, German, British. They're enemy.  Sorin and Vershinin discover the last of their men, all dead.)
We are the last two.
This isn't war. This is massacre.
The Ultima machine has done this.
Destroy it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They check their ammunition supply.

Dialogue.Line: Go that way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bates has followed Millington, and is eavesdropping. The haemovore is there.

Dialogue.Line: Your creatures are killing my men! What is it?
We call him the Great Serpent.
And the Great Serpent shall rise from the sea and spew venom over all the Earth.
There's enough poison in here to contaminate the world forever.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Bates runs up to the Doctor and Ace.

Dialogue.Line: They're insane. They're trying to control the world with chemical weapons.
All part of Fenric's evil game, no doubt, like this weather.
I know. (Sorin comes up behind Bates, who turns to him.)
Let's join forces, fight the real enemy.
That's a really good idea.
So we're all on the same side again?
You have the spirit of a fighter. And you wear our emblem.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace has a red star on her black jacket, which she is carrying.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's not a real one. I bought it cheap in a market.
Have the real one, tovarich.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin pins his own badge on her lapel, then takes her hand and gently kisses it.

Dialogue.Line: Come on! We've got to get Kathleen's chess set.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The marines arrive to rescue the Wrens.

Dialogue.Line: It's all right, girls. We'll take over now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Wrens turn around to show their pale faces and long nails. Once again, too late. Leigh is left to die as the other marines flee.

Dialogue.Line: Ace!
The chess set?
In the suitcase.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor grabs the chess set and runs for the door.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, don't leave me!
I can't leave them. I'll stay here.
Well, don't leave the hut.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin sees the smashed radios then turns to discover Jean and Phyllis have been hiding behind the door.

Dialogue.Line: You don't have the emblem this time.
But I still have my faith.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He does, and leaves safely.
Nurse Crane has put on her coat and is about to leave when two haemovores enter.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no! Oh, please! Please! Please!
Nurse Crane. You've looked after me all these years. Almost a mother, treating me like a child, humiliating me. I feel this is what Doctor Judson would have wished.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Possessed Judson gestures for the haemovores to do their work.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no! No, please! Argh!
We've got to do something about this room.
All right. Let me just sort the baby out, okay?
Let's use the furniture.
Right, let's put that bunk up against the door.
Okay. What about the wardrobe over the window?
Good idea. Let's use that and the other bunks up against the window.
Yeah.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Vershinin goes to the Ultima machine.

Dialogue.Line: I'm afraid you've had a wasted journey.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Millington shoots Vershinin.

Dialogue.Line: But then you were never really our allies, were you? Your people will always be the enemy.
See you in hell.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sets up the chess set in the munitions bunker.
Fortifications complete, the two women and baby sit and wait.

Dialogue.Line: I don't like dark buildings. There was one in Perivale, an old, empty house full of noises. Evil. Things I didn't understand. Undercurrents.
What kind of a world is this to bring up a child in?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A haemovore breaks in a window.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, the window!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace runs to the opposite window and starts to climb out.

Dialogue.Line: Ace, take Audrey.
Quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is placing the chess pieces for his puzzle.

Dialogue.Line: That's it. No, that's not right! It was so long ago. There.
In the jeep. Get in. Quick!
Where shall I go? What shall I do?
Go to London. My Nan'll look after you.
Where?
She lives in Streatham. Seventeen Old Terrace. Say it.
Seventeen Old Terrace. Wait, Ace. I want you to have this.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kathleen gives Ace a photograph of Audrey.

Dialogue.Line: (to Audrey) I'll always love you. Now go! (Kathleen puts Audrey behind the drivers seat.)
Seventeen Old Terrace.
Seventeen Old Terrace. Seventeen Old Terrace.
Now go! Go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kathleen drives the little covered jeep away. Jean and Phyllis walk up to Ace.

Dialogue.Line: The Time Lord has made his move. Take the poison. Carry it to the ocean. Release it into the waters.
And the other haemovores?
Oh yes, they've been so useful. How could we have managed without them. You know how to kill them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovore concentrates. Outside, Jean and Phyllis scream and collapse, then crumble into dust before Ace's eyes.
Judson enters.

Dialogue.Line: Where is the game, Time Lord?
You couldn't resist it, could you? The game of traps. The contest as before. One move. Find the winning move. Spring the trap on me, if you can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves Judson to pore over the chess board.
Captain Bates has found Vershinin. Millington enters and he points his service revolver at his superior.

Dialogue.Line: Are you going to use that gun? You know your problem, Captain Bates? You don't know who the enemy is. A traitor is someone who doesn't know who the enemy is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Millington raises his own weapon, a shot rings out and he falls.

Dialogue.Line: But I do.
I've been waiting.
You know me?
Thousands of years in the future, the Earth lies dying, the surface just a chemical slime. Half a million years of industrial progress.
I am the last. The last living creature on Earth. I watched my world dying with chemicals, and I could do nothing. My world is dead.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Judson is concentrating on the chess set when Ace runs in. He doesn't look up.

Dialogue.Line: Who is it? Is that you, Time Lord? Tell me the solution. The contest is, is too much for such a weak body.
I don't know the solution.
Tell me. Tell me the solution.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace runs out again.

Dialogue.Line: You're very patient. Carried back thousands of years in a time storm, to 9th century Transylvania, and waiting till now.
Without the flask, I was trapped.
Oh yes, the flask. I trapped him like an evil genie.
Only he can return me to the future.
And so, like a faithful servant, you follow the flask.
A merchant bought it from Constantinople. I followed him through Europe. I followed the Viking pirates who stole it, and I followed it here.

Another of Fenric's games. He carries you back in a time storm to destroy the Earth's water with chemicals, to destroy your future. Think on it. Your Earth, your world, dying of a chemical slime. This act will be the beginning of your end.
I owe you one.
What's happened? Are you all right?
We're all right now. We're fighting together now.
War, a game played by politicians. We were just pawns in the game, but the pawns are fighting together now. Eh, comrade?
That's it. The solution. The winning move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin enters, carrying a rifle.

Dialogue.Line: Where have you been?
It's time to die, Fenric.
You don't understand. You don't know why you were selected for this mission.
Because I speak English. My grandmother was English.
Emily Wilson, granddaughter of Joseph Sundvik. You are touched by the Curse of Fenric. I selected you. You are one of the Wolves of Fenric.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin takes aim.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure you can stand?
Workers of the world unite, comrade.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They clasp hands.
Sorin is studying the problem when Ace enters.

Dialogue.Line: Fenric would never have guessed the solution, anyway.
Tell me, tovarich.
A brilliant move. The black and white pawns don't fight each other, they join forces.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin turns and reveals his glowing green eyes.

Dialogue.Line: Thank you, child.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters.

Dialogue.Line: Ace!
Black wins, Time Lord.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He knocks over the white king and laughs. Lightning blasts through the roof and sets the board alight.

Dialogue.Line: What's happened?
The Wolves of Fenric, descendants of the Viking who first buried the flask, all pawns in my game. Doctor Judson, Commander Millington, the Ancient One, Captain Sorin, and now you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ancient One is behind Ace.

Dialogue.Line: Me? You can't! How?
The baby. In thirty years, the baby will be grown. She will have a daughter. That daughter will be you. You've just created your own future.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin holds Audrey's photograph in front of Ace.

Dialogue.Line: The baby is your mother. The mother you hate. Kill them, slowly.
You don't stand a chance. Tell him, Doctor. He's got it wrong.
The Time Lord has failed. The Wolves of Fenric have released me.
The Doctor never fails. I've got faith in him. Complete faith.
Kill them.
It can't penetrate Ace's psychic force.
Time for the one final game, then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Sorin picks up a poison vial and holds it near Ace's head.

Dialogue.Line: The choice is yours, Time Lord. I shall kill you anyway, but if you would like the girl to live, kneel before me.
I believe in you, Professor.
Kneel, if you want the girl to live!
Kill her.
The Time Lord finally understands.
Do you think I didn't know? The chess set in Lady Peinforte's study? I knew.
Earlier than that, Time Lord. Before Cybermen, ever since Ice World, where you first met the girl.

I knew. I knew she carried the evil inside her. Do you think I'd have chosen a social misfit if I hadn't known? She couldn't even pass her chemistry exams at school, and yet she manages to create a time storm in her bedroom. I saw your hand in it from the very beginning.
Doctor, no.
She's an emotional cripple. I wouldn't waste my time on her, unless I had to use her somehow.
No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace falls to her knees.

Dialogue.Line: Kill them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovore picks the payload of one of the bombs and walks towards Sorin, who backs away.

Dialogue.Line: Kill them, do you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It backs Sorin into the containment chamber.

Dialogue.Line: No! No. I command you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The haemovore follows Sorin in and shuts the door behind them.

Dialogue.Line: No! No! No! No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ancient One drops the payload, breaking the vials and filling the chamber with the deadly gas. They both die.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. It's over.
Leave me alone!
We've got to get out of here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor pulls Ace to her feet and pushes her outside.

Dialogue.Line: Leave me alone!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They slither and fall in the mud as there is an explosion in the bunker.

Dialogue.Line: Couldn't even pass a chemistry exam.
I'd have done anything not to hurt you, but I had to save you from Fenric's evil curse. Your faith in me was holding the haemovore back.
You said I was an emotional cripple, a social misfit.
I had to make you lose your belief in me.
Full marks for teenage psychology.
It's not true, believe me.
I don't love her! She's my mum, and I don't love her! What's wrong with me? Why can't I stop hating her?
You loved the baby.
But I didn't know she was my mum!
Love and hate, frightening feelings, especially when they're trapped struggling beneath the surface. Don't be frightened of the water.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace pulls off her snood and dives in.

Dialogue.Line: Audrey. It's all right, darling.
I'll always love you. I'll always love you. I'll always love you.
It's all right, darling. It's all right, darling.
I'll always love you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ace splashes to the shore.

Dialogue.Line: I'm not scared now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They walk back up the shingle to the warning sign.

Dialogue.Line: Dangerous undercurrents, Doctor?
Not any more. Niet.
